notes.text:
SCALANCE LPE9403 is affected by multiple vulnerabilities that could allow an attacker to impact its confidentiality, integrity and availability.

Siemens has released a new version for SCALANCE LPE9403 and recommends to update to the latest version.
notes.title: Summary

notes.text:
As a general security measure, Siemens strongly recommends to protect network access to devices with appropriate mechanisms. In order to operate the devices in a protected IT environment, Siemens recommends to configure the environment according to Siemens' operational guidelines for Industrial Security (Download: 
https://www.siemens.com/cert/operational-guidelines-industrial-security), and to follow the recommendations in the product manuals.
Additional information on Industrial Security by Siemens can be found at: https://www.siemens.com/industrialsecurity
notes.title: General Recommendations

notes.text: For further inquiries on security vulnerabilities in Siemens products and solutions, please contact the Siemens ProductCERT: https://www.siemens.com/cert/advisories
notes.title: Additional Resources

notes.text: The use of Siemens Security Advisories is subject to the terms and conditions listed on: https://www.siemens.com/productcert/terms-of-use.
notes.title: Terms of Use

references.summary: SSA-075201: Multiple Vulnerabilities in SCALANCE LPE9403 Before V4.0 - HTML Version
SSA-075201: Multiple Vulnerabilities in SCALANCE LPE9403 Before V4.0 - CSAF Version

document.title: SSA-075201: Multiple Vulnerabilities in SCALANCE LPE9403 Before V4.0

cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')

notes.text:
Affected devices do not properly sanitize user input when creating new VXLAN configurations.
This could allow an authenticated highly-privileged remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the device.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V4.0 or later version

cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')

notes.text:
Affected devices do not properly sanitize user input when creating new users.
This could allow an authenticated highly-privileged remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the device.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V4.0 or later version

cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')

notes.text:
Affected devices do not properly sanitize user input when creating new SNMP users.
This could allow an authenticated highly-privileged remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the device.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V4.0 or later version

cwe.name: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')

notes.text:
Affected devices do not properly limit the scope of files accessible through and the privileges of the SFTP functionality.
This could allow an authenticated highly-privileged remote attacker to read and write arbitrary files.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V4.0 or later version

notes.text:
Affected devices do not properly limit the elevation of privileges required to perform certain valid functionality.
This could allow an authenticated lowly-privileged remote attacker to escalate their privileges.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V4.0 or later version

cwe.name: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')

notes.text:
Affected devices do not properly limit user controlled paths to which logs are written and from where they are read.
This could allow an authenticated highly-privileged remote attacker to read and write arbitrary files in the filesystem, if and only if the malicious path ends with 'log' .
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V4.0 or later version

cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')

notes.text:
Affected devices do not properly neutralize special characters when interpreting user controlled log paths.
This could allow an authenticated highly-privileged remote attacker to execute a limited set of binaries that are already present on the filesystem.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V4.0 or later version
